values.alignmentText: Slovenia's ~60% forest cover, clean rivers, and strong recycling keep air, water, and green space quality high for an outdoorsy family.
Slovenia is generally mild, but hotter summers and regional flood risks demand resilience planning. Prioritize flood-resistant housing and insurance.
Slovenia offers mild springs and autumns, warm but not humid summers, and snowy winters, great for outdoor family life.
Ljubljana-area air is generally decent; winter inversions can raise PM2.5 to moderate levels monthly. Masks on bad days for the kids.
Moderate seismicity and river floods in Slovenia; strong building codes help, but preparation and site choice still shape family risk.
Ljubljana spring is mild but variable: warm afternoons with cool mornings, prompting wardrobe adjustments; pack layers and expect occasional showers.
Slovenia summers typically hover around 30°C (86°F) with moderate humidity; occasional heatwaves reach mid-30s°C, but nights stay cool.
Autumn in Slovenia (SI) is mostly mild with light sweater weather; occasional showers may occur.
Slovenia's winters are generally mild; Ljubljana ranges -3 to 5°C with light snow. Primorska stays milder, and heating plus snow tires usually suffice.
Adriatic coast near Koper-Portorož offers tidy pebble beaches within short trips; some spots lack shade or lifeguards, but family-friendly overall.
Slovenia's Piran Bay sits about 24-26 C in peak summer; most swim-season months are 22-26 C, shoulder months need light rash guards.
Slovenia's Lake Bled, Bohinj, and karst caves near Ljubljana offer stunning, family-friendly scenery with easy, year-round hikes.
Ljubljana rents: min wage €1,254 gross (~€878 net) barely covers a family of four. With two kids, dual incomes or allowances are common.
Slovenia senior software pay runs around €45–60k gross locally, below Western Europe. Remote or freelance work helps Trey hit goals.
Steady but niche .NET demand in Ljubljana/Maribor, Slovenia; remote/hybrid roles growing, though many openings in larger EU hubs.
In Slovenia, Ruby roles are sporadic. Most openings favor hybrid work or remote EU contracts.

Slovenia standard 40-hour week with regulated overtime; hybrid/remote options support family balance and predictable hours.

In Slovenia, typical paid leave is about 25-29 days. Downtime is encouraged to support family trips.

Slovenia offers safe, family-friendly neighborhoods, universal healthcare, and strong schools; generous parental leave and affordable childcare support families with kids.
Polyamory is discreet in Slovenia. Ljubljana's urban scenes are welcoming, but official channels lag in recognition.
Slovenia's family-friendly policies support shared parenting and early education. Your values fit dual involvement and education focus in a calmer setting.

Slovenia offers public childcare subsidies, but visa families may face waitlists and residency proofs; private care often used.

Visa families can enroll children in Slovenian public schools, but must provide residence proof and may need Slovene immersion with variable ESL support.
Ljubljana has few reputable private schools; two international options (British and American) with €10–18k/year tuition and waitlists.
Slovenia offers strong parental leave, childcare support, and universal healthcare that fit your family priorities. Bureaucracy can slow payments.
In Slovenia, visa-holding families have access to some social and health benefits. However, many regular supports require longer residency or permanent status.
Slovenia offers broad access to public universities with low tuition for citizens and Erasmus options; newcomers can explore residency-based aid and scholarships.
Non-EU adults pay €3–8k/yr at Slovenian public universities. English-taught programs exist, but visa/residency steps add friction.
Slovenia generally supports egalitarian work and caregiving with parental leave. Urban Slovenia leans toward shared roles; some traditional norms persist.
Slovenia's urban centers show strong social acceptance of gender diversity, but legal documents lag behind everyday inclusion.
In Slovenia, gender protections are strong and pay equity rules exist; enforcement is improving, with some sector gaps.
Slovenia generally affords women broad autonomy. Urban areas support dual careers with only mild appearance/parenting pressures.
Slovenia's evolving norms support hands-on dads and openness; nontraditional roles are broadly accepted, with occasional teasing.
Slovenia's Alps offer winter fun, lakes and caves for kids, and a sunny Adriatic coast. Compact, safe, and design-savvy, it's ideal for family exploration.
Ljubljana, Slovenia: English is common for daily life and services, but government forms favor Slovene; we'll study the local language for full participation.
Slovenia (SI) leans progressive with strong civic engagement; LGBTQ+ rights and universal healthcare support the family's values.

Slovenia generally tolerates atheism; secular life is common. Some official rituals and public events still lean Catholic.
Slovenia offers comprehensive sex education and easy contraception; urban areas like Ljubljana are liberal, with generally progressive attitudes.
Same-sex marriage legal; Pride events in Ljubljana/Maribor; rural towns can be cautious, but comprehensive protections exist.
Slovenia's friendly but reserved neighborhoods; expat groups and schools help kids settle, with local events aiding gradual integration.
Slovenia sees itself as eco-friendly, innovative, and cooperative; in Ljubljana you will find safe, English-friendly, family-focused communities.
Generally amicable with Austria, Italy, Hungary, and Croatia; Schengen travel eases border life, though Croatia debates appear in media.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Neighbors Austria, Italy, and Croatia view Slovenia as a stable EU partner with strong tourism ties; occasional policy debates exist, but no major tensions.
